lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've seen that with an INNER JOIN, items that don't match the condition, like 0267, Lin Wong, aren't selected.

Make sure to type INNER JOIN.

lessons.title: Intro 2
lessons.interactiveContent: That's because the INNER JOIN only keeps matching rows.

lessons.title: LEFT JOIN
lessons.interactiveContent:
To get matching rows, but also keep the ones without a match from the first table, we use a LEFT JOIN.

Make sure to type LEFT JOIN.

lessons.title: LEFT JOIN 2
lessons.interactiveContent: Notice in the diagram, that the LEFT JOIN selects the entire left table, plus the matching rows from the right table.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Looking at the diagram, which items from the left table should appear in the results of a LEFT JOIN?

Only those that have a match in the right tableNone of themAll rows, regardless of whether they have a match or not

All rows, regardless of whether they have a match or not.

lessons.title: LEFT JOIN 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Left-table items will be in the results whether they have a match or not.

Right-table items will appear only if they have a match in the left table.

lessons.title: Left and right tables
lessons.interactiveContent:
We call the first table that we select the left table, like student here.

Make sure to type student.

lessons.title: Left and right tables 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
The table we join is the right table, like enrolled here.

Make sure to type enrolled.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now that we know about left and right tables, which table from this query gets to keep all its items?

studentenrolled

Make sure to pick student.

lessons.title: Question: Intro 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
When do we use an INNER JOIN?

When we only want to keep matching rows from both tablesWhen we want all the rows from both tables

When we only want to keep matching rows from both tables.

lessons.title: Question: LEFT JOIN
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can we get all left-table items plus any existing matches in the right table?

With a LEFT JOINWith a RIGHT JOIN

With a LEFT JOIN.

lessons.title: Question: LEFT JOIN 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this query select?

All artist items and any matching album itemsOnly artist items that have a match in the album table

All artist items and any matching album items.

lessons.title: Question: LEFT JOIN 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which items from the right table does this query select?

Only those that have a match in the artist tableAll of them

Only those that have a match in the artist table.

lessons.title: Question: Left and right tables
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which is the left table in this query?

album, since it's the one we selectartist, since it's the one we join

album, since it's the one we select.

lessons.title: Question: Left and right tables 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which is the right table in this query?

artist, since it's the one we joinalbum since it's the one we select

artist, since it's the one we join.

lessons.title: Example: Intro 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Join the tables so that the results contain only matching rows from both tables.

Make sure to pick INNER, followed by JOIN.

lessons.title: Example: LEFT JOIN
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use a LEFT JOIN to get all items from artist and only the matching ones from album.

Make sure to type LEFT JOIN.

lessons.title: Example: Left and right tables
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set artist as the left table and album as the right table.

Make sure to pick FROM followed by artist and then LEFT, JOIN, album.

lessons.title: Select left table
lessons.interactiveContent:
To use a LEFT JOIN, we start by selecting a left table, like student. This table will keep all its entries.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by * and then FROM, student, ;.

lessons.title: LEFT JOIN right table
lessons.interactiveContent:
We then code LEFT JOIN, followed by the right table, enrolled.

Make sure to type LEFT JOIN enrolled.

lessons.title: ON
lessons.interactiveContent:
Just like with INNER JOIN, we use ON to set a condition for matching rows from the two tables.

Make sure to type ON.

lessons.title: Condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
We'll want to connect rows having a matching property, like the student.id matching enrolled.student_id.

Make sure to pick . followed by id and then =, enrolled, ., student_id.

lessons.title: Specific columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
To further refine the result table, we can select specific columns, like student.name and enrolled.class.

Make sure to pick . followed by name and then ,, enrolled.class.

lessons.title: Aliasing
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finally, we can also use column or table aliases. Rename student to s and enrolled to e.

Make sure to pick AS followed by s and then AS, e.

lessons.title: Question: ON
lessons.interactiveContent:
Do we need an ON clause when using a LEFT JOIN?

Yes, to introduce a condition for matching rowsNo, since the LEFT JOIN selects all items anyway

Yes, to introduce a condition for matching rows.

lessons.title: Question: Condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the condition for matching items in this LEFT JOIN query?

album.artist_id = artist.idLEFT JOIN artist

album.artist_id = artist.id.

lessons.title: Question: Specific columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which columns will appear in the result table?

name and titleartist.name and album.title

name and title.

lessons.title: Question: Aliasing
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why does this query access the artist's name property with a.name?

Because a is the alias of artistBecause a is the alias of album

Because a is the alias of artist.

lessons.title: Example: Select left table
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select all artist items so that we can later use a LEFT JOIN.

Make sure to type FROM artist.

lessons.title: Example: LEFT JOIN right table
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use a LEFT JOIN to connect matching items from the album table.

Make sure to type LEFT JOIN album.

lessons.title: Example: ON
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a keyword that lets us define a condition for matching table rows.

Make sure to pick ON.

lessons.title: Example: Condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write a condition to match artist and album rows only if the artist's id matches the album's artist_id.

Make sure to type = album.artist_id.

lessons.title: Example: Specific columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add a comma , and select the album table's title column.

Make sure to type , album.title.

lessons.title: Example: Aliasing
lessons.interactiveContent:
Rename the selected name column to artist, and title to album.

Make sure to pick AS followed by artist and then AS, album.

lessons.title: Empty cells
lessons.interactiveContent:
With LEFT JOIN, left-table items without a match, like 0267, Lin Wong, appear connected to empty table cells.

Make sure to pick LEFT, followed by JOIN.

lessons.title: Right-table items
lessons.interactiveContent:
Right-table items without a match, like 1222, History, don't appear in the result table at all.

Make sure to pick LEFT, followed by JOIN, and finally enrolled.

lessons.title: Multiple matches
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's look at multiple matches. We've changed the enrolled table so that there are two matches for student 1008.

Make sure to type enrolled.

lessons.title: Multiple matches 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Like with INNER JOIN, multiple-match items appear once for every match. Notice the double 1008, Luz Garcia.

Make sure to pick = followed by enrolled and then ., student_id.

lessons.title: Query explanation
lessons.interactiveContent:
This query uses a LEFT JOIN to select all students, along with their classes if they enrolled in any.

Make sure to pick student, followed by LEFT JOIN, and finally enrolled.

lessons.title: Question: Empty cells
lessons.interactiveContent:
When might we see empty cells in the result table of a LEFT JOIN, like in the image below?

When a row in the left table has no match in the right tableWhen a row in the left table has multiple matches in the right table

When a row in the left table has no match in the right table.

lessons.title: Question: Right-table items
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we switch tables and make album the left one, which item won't appear in the results?

3, Bill Evans because it has no match in the left table1, John Coltrane because it has no match in the left table

3, Bill Evans because it has no match in the left table.

lessons.title: Question: Multiple matches
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which item from which table will appear in the results multiple times?

1, John Coltrane from artist1, Blue Train from album

1, John Coltrane from artist.

lessons.title: Example: Empty cells
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set artist as the left table and notice that 3, Bill Evans still appears in the results, despite not having a match.

Make sure to type FROM artist.

lessons.title: Example: Multiple matches
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use a LEFT JOIN to find matching album rows, and notice that 1, John Coltrane has two matches.

Make sure to type LEFT JOIN album.

lessons.title: Example: Query explanation
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write a query to get all artist items, along with any matching albums.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by * and then FROM, artist, LEFT, JOIN, album.
